title-group.article-title: Innovative three-dimensional fabric structure with negative Poisson's ratio for composite reinforcement

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Textiles and Clothing, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Hong Hu, Institute of Textiles and Clothing, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong. Email: tchuhong@polyu.edu.hk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents an innovative three-dimensional (3D) fabric structure for composite reinforcement. Different from most conventional 3D fabric structures, the new structure displays a negative Poisson’s ratio (NPR) effect under compression. Based on a manufacturing process developed by combining both non-weaving and knitting technologies, four NPR 3D fabric samples with different warp yarn diameters were first manufactured manually. Then, their Poisson’s ratio (PR) values under compression along the fabric thickness direction were experimentally evaluated. A geometrical model was also proposed for the theoretical calculation of PR values of these fabrics and was compared with experimental data. The good agreements were obtained between the calculation and experiment. The results show that all the 3D fabrics display NPR effect under compression, which results in a unique feature that allows the structure to concentrate itself under the compressive load to better resist the load. This special feature makes this innovative 3D fabric structure very attractive for many potential applications such as automobile, aerospace, defense and sports equipment, where impact protection can be a highly desirable property.

body.p: The Poisson’s ratio (PR) is defined as the negative ratio of the lateral strain to the longitudinal strain when a load is applied to the longitudinal direction of a material.1 For all common materials, Poisson’s ratio is positive, such as approximately 0.5 for rubbers and soft biological tissues, 0.45 for lead, 0.33 for aluminum, 0.27 for common steels, 0.1 to 0.4 for typical polymer foams, nearly zero for cork2 and so on. That Poisson’s ratio may possibly be negative for materials has been an accepted consequence of the classical elasticity theory for more than 150 years.3 Since Lakes manufactured the first non-natural isotropic foam having negative Poisson’s ratio (NPR) from conventional open-cell foam,2 interest in NPR materials has continued as it became known that a negative Poisson’s ratio may significantly increase many of the effective mechanical properties of a material,2,4 for example, enhanced shear modulus and indentation resistance.5 To date, a number of NPR materials have been discovered, fabricated, or synthesized, ranging from the macroscopic down to the molecular levels.6 The NPR polymeric materials, including polyurethane (PU),7 polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE),5 ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE),8 polypropylene (PP)9 and nylon,10 have successfully been produced, and models to understand the deformation mechanisms giving rise to the NPR effect have been developed as well. It has been proved that the NPR effect can be achieved by special geometrical arrangements. The geometrical structures to achieve NPR include the re-entrant structures, chiral structures, rotating units, angle-ply laminates, hard molecules, microporous polymers and free-rod liquid crystalline polymers, etc.6,11

In recent years, the development of NPR materials using textile technology has attracted great attention.12 Alderson et al. developed a continuous partial melt extrusion process using the batch-processing route to produce NPR polymeric monofilaments.13 Based on the process developed, they made NPR polypropylene, polyester and nylon monofilaments with diameters in the range of 0.14–1 mm.14 Evans et al. produced a multifilament having NPR behavior when stretched.15 The multifilament consists of a thicker, low-stiffness filament and a high-stiffness filament wrapped helically around it. Miller et al. employed woven fabrics made with NPR yarns to produce auxetic composites.16 Samuel et al. produced warp-knitted fabrics made of re-entrant meshes having an NPR effect.17,18 Starbuck et al. patented NPR warp-knitted fabrics.19 Most recently, a series of auxetic knitted fabrics based on different geometrical structures such as foldable structures, rotating rectangles and reentrant hexagons have been produced by Hu et al.11,20 However, all NPR fabrics found in the literature are produced only with single fabric forming technology, i.e. weaving or knitting technology, and some of them are not very suitable for composite reinforcement.

This paper reports a new NPR three-dimensional (3D) fabric structure for composite reinforcement. Using the manufacturing process based on both non-weaving and knitting technologies, four NPR 3D fabric samples with different warp yarn diameters were manufactured and their PR values under compression were experimentally evaluated. A geometrical model was proposed for the prediction of the PR values of these fabrics from the given structural parameters. Both experimental and calculating results were compared. The results have shown that all the 3D fabrics display NPR effect under compression, which results in a unique feature that allows the structure to concentrate itself under the compressive load to better resist the load. This special feature makes this kind of 3D fabric structure very attractive for many potential applications such as automobile, aerospace, defense and sports equipment, where impact protection can be a highly desirable property.

sec.title: Fabric structure and manufacturing process
sec.p:
The 3D NPR fabric structure is shown in Figure 1. It is composed of three yarn systems, i.e. weft yarns, warp yarns and stitch yarns. As shown in Figure 1(a), the weft and warp yarns are not interlaced. They are alternately arranged along two orthogonal directions of the fabric plan and are bound together by the stitch yarns through the fabric thickness direction to form an integrated fabric structure. For producing the NPR effect along the weft direction, the warp yarns in each layer are placed one in and one out, and the positions of all of the warp yarns in two neighboring layers are alternated by half yarn spacing. At the initial state, both the weft and warp yarn are in a straight form. However, under compression along the fabric thickness direction, as shown in Figure 1(b), the weft yarns will get crimped, which results in a shrinkage of the structure in the weft directions. Since the weft yarns are fully arranged, the shape of the warp yarns remain unchanged under compression. As a result, the size of the fabric structure is unchanged in the warp direction. Therefore, the structure will have the NPR in the weft direction and zero Poisson’s ratio in the warp direction under compression. Figure 1.
Three-dimensional (3D) NPR textile structure: (a) initial state; (b) under compression.

The cross section of the 3D NPR structure is shown in Figure 2, in which the NPR effect of the 3D NPR structure in the weft direction under compression can be better demonstrated. As shown in Figure 2(a), a repeating unit of the structure is outlined by breaking lines. It is necessary to point out that the spaces between the warp yarns are used to produce the NPR effect. This may result in the reduction of the stability of the structure. As this NPR structure is developed for composite reinforcement, the compressible matrix will be filled in the voice spaces of the structure to make the composite. Therefore, the stability of the composite structure will be ensured. Figure 2.
The cross-section of the three-dimensional (3D) auxetic structure: (a) initial state; (b) under compression.

To fabricate this 3D NPR fabric structure, a special textile manufacturing process that combines both the non-weaving and knitting technologies has been proposed. The manufacturing process is schematically demonstrated in Figure 3. A complete fabric-forming sequence consists of several steps. In the first step (Figure 3(a)), the previous fabric-forming sequence has just finished and the needle has reached its lowest or initial position. In the second step (Figure 3(b)), the fabric that has just formed is taken out from the fabric-forming area through the take-up mechanism. At the same time, the stitch yarn guide swings to the back position of the needle, which is kept immobile. In the third step (Figure 3(c)), the first group of the warp yarns is inserted into the weft yarns. The needle is kept immobile. In the fourth step (Figure 3(d)), the needle will rise and reaches its highest position. In the fifth step (Figure 3(e)), the needle goes down and takes the stitch yarn fed by the yarn guide to form a new loop. Then, the next fabric-forming sequence, in which the second group of the warp yarns with an alternate position should be inserted, will restart. The above explanation shows that a complete process includes two forming sequences. By repeating this process, a 3D auxetic fabric structure can be produced. Figure 3.
Manufacturing process: (a) initial position; (b) take-up of the fabric; (c) insertion of the warp yarns; (d) needle at the highest position; (e) needle at the lowest position and completion of the sequence.

sec.title: Sample production and compression test
sec.p: A prototype to produce this new 3D NPR fabric structure is being developed at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University based on the above manufacturing process. To verify the feasibility of the process, four kinds of 3D NPR fabrics were first produced by hand with four different types of warp yarns. According to a preliminary study, it was found that if the same type of yarn was used for both the weft and warp yarns, the NPR effect of the structure would not be very obvious. In order to facilitate the manufacturing process and to increase the NPR effect of the structure, four rigid braided yarns made of polyamide fiber were used as warp yarns, and flexible braid was used as weft yarns. For the stitch yarn, an elastic yarn, whose diameter is much smaller than that of the weft and warp yarns, was used for a better binding effect. The elasticity of the stitch yarn was selected in such a way that the whole structure can be held by stitches without causing the obvious deformation of the weft yarns at the initial state. In this study, the stitch yarn used is a core-spandex yarn 0.6 mm in diameter.

In order to facilitate the comparison, both the weft yarns’ spacing and warp yarns’ spacing were kept unchanged for all the fabrics. The structural parameters of the samples produced are listed in Table 1. Photographs of four fabric samples are shown in Figure 4(a) and (b), respectively. It is can be seen that under the action of the stitch yarn tension, the weft yarns cannot be kept totally straight at the initial state. So this initial effect should be taken into consideration during the geometrical analysis of the structure. Figure 4.
Photographs of three-dimensional (3D) fabric samples.
Table 1.
Structural parameters of the fabric samples produced
Sample Radius of braided yarn Yarn diameter’s ratio (r2/r1) Half weft yarns’ spacing l0 (mm) Half warp yarns’ spacing l0 (mm) Fabric thickness H (mm)
Weft yarn r1 (mm) Warp yarn r2 (mm)
a 1.012 3.083 3.046 2.79 7.343 46.82
b 1.012 2.621 2.590 2.76 7.393 42.27
c 1.012 2.279 2.252 2.77 7.393 37.45
d 1.012 1.736 1.715 2.75 7.421 30.59

The above produced samples were subjected to a compression test to assess their NPR effect in the weft direction. The compression test was conducted on an Instron 5566 machine equipped with two circular compression platens 150 mm in diameter at a speed of 2 mm/min. In order to measure the lateral size change, as shown in Figure 5, a digital camera placed at a distance of 50 cm from the fabric sample was used to record the distance change between the central points of two warp yarns marked with a black color. The marked yarns were selected in such a way that their yarn cross sections were on the same horizontal line close to the central plane of the fabric. The initial distance between the two marked yarns was first measured before compression. In order for the digital camera to easily take the image under stable conditions, the compression process was split into several equal compression intervals, and at the end of each interval, the compression platen was stopped for 30 seconds for picture taking. Figure 5.
Set-up of the testing system.

The lateral compression tests for single-weft yarn and warp yarns were also conducted on the Instron 5566 machine at a speed of 2 mm/min in order to establish the relationship between the yarn diameter change and compression loading. These relationships will be used in the theoretical calculation of PR values of the structure based on the geometrical model presented below.

sec.title: Geometrical model
sec.p:
In order to predict the NPR effect of the 3D fabric structure, a geometrical model, as shown in Figure 6, has been proposed. According to the observations of the fabric structure at the initial state and during the compression test, the following assumptions have been made for simplifying the analysis:
All the repeating units have the same geometrical shape and size. The stitch yarn has no effect on NPR effect and can be omitted from the geometrical analysis.
The warp yarns are always kept straight at both the initial and compression states because of higher rigidity.
The weft yarns are not totally straight at the initial state, and their central lines are formed with the straight lines and circular curves, which are connected together in such a way that the straight lines are tangent with the circular curves at the connecting points.
The cross sections of both the warp and weft yarns are in a circular form at the initial state and will be changed to an elliptical shape under the lateral compression action, but the cross-section areas remain unchanged. The major and minor axes of the elliptical shapes of both weft yarn and warp yarn under compression will be derived from the compression testing results of fabric and yarns.
The lengths of both the warp and weft yarns are kept constant under compression.
The central lines of the weft yarns under compression are formed with the straight lines and elliptic curves, which are connected together in such a way that the straight lines are tangent with the elliptic curves at the connecting points.
There is no slippage between the weft and warp yarns at their contact points during compression.
Figure 6.
The geometrical model of the three-dimensional 3D auxetic structure: (a) initial state; (b) under compression.

Based on the above assumptions, l0, h0, l and h as shown in Figure 6(a) and (b) can be obtained from the analysis of the geometrical model, and are given in equations (1) to (4), respectively. (1)lo=2(r1+r2)sinθo+[S-2(r1+r2)θ0]cosθ0 (2)ho=2(r1+r2)cosθ0-[S-2(r1+r2)θ0]sinθ0 (3)l=2Rsinθ+[S-2Rθ]cosθ (4)h=2Rcosθ+[S-2Rθ]sinθ-2R+2b where r1 and r2 are the initial radii of the warp yarn and weft yarn, respectively; θ0 and θ0 are the inclination angles of the straight line of the weft yarn at the initial state and under compression, respectively; S is the length of the weft yarn and is kept constant during compression; R is the radius of the elliptic curve of the weft yarn derived by the four-center method, and is given by equation (5). (5)R=[(a2+b2+a-b)]a2+b22b where a = a1 + b2; b = b1 + b2; a1 = r12/b1; a2 = r22/b2; a1, a2, b1 and b2 are the major semi-axes and minor semi-axes of the cross sections of the warp yarn and weft yarn under compression, respectively. The values of a1, a2, b1 and b2 depend on the type of yarns used. They are derived by experiment in this study. When l0, h0, l and h are known, Poisson’s ratio ν of the structure in the weft direction can be calculated according to equation (6): (6)v=-ɛlɛh=l-l0l0h-h0h0=-h0(l-l0)l0(h-h0) where ɛl and ɛh are the lateral strain and compression strain, respectively.

sec.title: NPR effect of the structure
sec.p:
The PR-compression strain curves of four fabric samples obtained by compression test along the fabric direction are shown in Figure 7. It can be seen that the PR values of all four fabrics are negative. This experimentally confirms that the proposed 3D textile structure has an NPR effect. The curves in Figure 7 also show that the NPR effect of all the fabrics increases by increasing the compression strain. In addition, the ratio between warp and weft yarn diameters has a significant effect on the NPR effect. To obtain high NPR effect, high yarn diameter ratio is required. Figure 7.
PR-compression strain curves.

sec.title: Comparison between the experiment and calculation
sec.p:
In order to compare the results from both the experiment and calculation, the structural parameters h0, S and θ0 of each fabric sample at the initial state, as shown in Figure 6(a), should first be calculated from the values of the other parameters listed in Table 1. The height of the half unit cell h0 is directly calculated from the fabric thickness H. When h0 is known, S and θ0 can be calculated by solving Equations (1) and (2). The calculated values of h0, S and θ0 of four fabric samples are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Structural parameters of fabrics at the initial state
Sample h0 (mm) S (mm) θ0 (rad)
a 6.78 7.489 0.215
b 6.17 7.478 0.159
c 5.48 7.478 0.159
d 4.52 7.487 0.138

Under the lateral compression, the cross-sections of both the weft yarn and warp yarns are changed from the circular shape to the elliptical shape according to assumption 4. In this study, the experimental results obtained from the compression tests of fabric samples (Figure 8) and single weft and warp yarns (Figure 9) are used to derive the values of the major and minor axes of the cross sections of the weft yarn and warp yarn during the compression process. The small peaks on the curves in Figure 8 originate from the stops of the movable compression platen at the end of each compression interval for picture taking. From the curves in Figure 8, it is possible to derive the load applied at each yarn contact point by dividing the compression load of the fabric by the number of total yarn contact points in each yarn layer, which are 300 for all four fabric samples. When the load at each yarn contact point is known, the minor axes b1 and b2 of both warp yarn and weft yarn can be derived from the curves in Figure 9. When b1 and b2 are known, the major axes a1 and a2 can be calculated as the cross-section areas of both the warp yarn and weft yarn are assumed to remain unchanged under compression. When a1, a2, b1 and b2 are known, the Poison’s ratio ν can be easily calculated by solving Equations (3)–(6). Figure 8.
Compression curves of fabric samples.
Figure 9.
Compression curves of single warp and weft yarns.

The PR-compression strain curves of four fabric samples obtained from the calculation are shown in Figure 10 and are compared with the experimental model. For better presentation, both the experimental and calculated curves of each fabric sample are separately shown in Figure 10(a)–(d). It can be seen that the calculated curves are close to the experimental ones for all the fabric samples. This means that the proposed geometrical model can be used to predict the NPR effect of the 3D NPR fabric structure if the cross-sectional changes of the weft and warp yarns under compression are determined by experiment. Figure 10.
Comparison between experiment and calculation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
An innovative 3D NPR fabric structure was developed based on both non-weaving and knitting technologies. Four fabric samples with different structural parameters were produced and their PR values were experimentally assessed. A geometrical model was proposed and was compared with experimental results. Some conclusions can be drawn from the study:
It is possible to achieve an NPR effect in a 3D fabric structure by using a suitable yarn arrangement that can be realized by combining both non-weaving and knitting technologies.
The suitable selection of structural parameters is important to achieve the desired NPR effect. The high yarn fineness ratio between the warp and weft yarns can be used to obtain a high NPR effect of the structure when other structural parameters are kept unchanged.
The NPR effect of the structure is not constant. It increases as the compression strain increases. The geometrical model can be used to predict the NPR effect of the structure with given structural parameters.
A 3D NPR fabric structure is expected to be used for composite reinforcement. It can concentrate itself under the compressive load, which makes it very attractive for many potential applications such as automobile, aerospace, defense and sports equipment, where impact protection can be a highly desirable property.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Research Grants Council of Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government (grant number PolyU5165/10E).

sec.title: Conflict of interest statement
sec.p: The authors confirm that there is no conflict of interest.
